thread.title: Munich's annual excuse to consume vast quantities of beer is over. Here are some of the facts and numbers that kept the party going

title: Munich's annual excuse to consume vast quantities of beer is over. Here are some of the facts and numbers that kept the party going
text:
CNN Leadership
Lost dentures, hangovers the size of Bavaria: What happened at Oktoberfest? By CNN Staff Updated 1122 GMT (1822 HKT) October 6, 2015 There's only one way to find out if of Germany beer purity laws mean smaller hangovers. Story highlights Oktoberfest is held every year in Munich in southern Germany The two-week event attracts millions of people from all over the world In their wake they left a trail of hangovers, vague recollections and, apparently, false teeth (CNN) In a flurry of upended steins, Munich's two-week Oktoberfest drew to a lightly sozzled close over the weekend. As hangovers subside, we've pulled together a few interesting stats from the 182nd edition of the original -- and still the best -- excuse for drinking beer while wearing a pair of embroidered leather shorts. Our best fact-gathering efforts mainly involved checking the excellent official Oktoberfest website , where the litany of abandoned objects, including false teeth and toilet brushes, makes sobering reading. The following infographic may also include some stuff we found scribbled on the back of slightly damp beer mat -- we're still trying to piece things together.
